headline.main: Entangled With War on Terror, Threat of Global Recession
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WORLD ECONOMY

lead_paragraph: For seven weeks now, President Bush has been preoccupied with managing a global war on terrorism. With the announcement today that the American economy shrank in the third quarter, he is faced with managing another complex and often intertwined crisis: The prospect of a global recession. The world's two largest economies -- the United States and Japan -- are in simultaneous retreat. Germany appears headed into the same morass, and Europe's growth is paltry. And one of the chief lessons of the 1990's, when successive economic crises rippled quickly around the world, was a simple one: the weakest economies are often the first pushed off the edge of the cliff.
abstract: David Sanger news analysis of shrinking world economy says ripple effects of terror attacks and aftermath will be felt througout Middle East as oil prices drop, and in fragile economies of developing countries and emerging markets; economist Allen Sinai says United States is positioned as scapegoat for global recession, but Sanger says assessment is unfair, that it was America that pulled world out of three major economic jolts in last seven years; Pres Bush contends that Congressional passage of economic stimulus package will help with world situation; article says this recession differs in that three continents are simultaneously affected and that effects will likely be political as well as economic; another factor discussed is Pakistan's volatile situation both economically and because of its close proximity to war in Afghanistan, making it unattractive for foreign investment; photo (M)
